text: Certamente i castelli di Linderhof e Neuschwanstein sono pi√π affascinati maIl castello di Nymphenburg, splendida residenza estiva dei re bavaresi: un tempo fuori citt√†, ormai inglobato nell'area urbana di Monaco di Baviera ha un suo perch√©.Il parco √® ad accesso libero, ma vale la pena di pagare il biglietto per visitare gli interni del palazzo e soprattutto i raffinati padiglioni del parco. Solo per questo motivo ha ordinato il palazzo di Nymphenburg nel 1664 in dono a sua moglie Adelheid di Savoia.Scultori, stuccatori e pittori pi√π ricercati del loro tempo sono autori delle finiture interne create sotto la guida di Fran√ßois de Cuvilli√©s e Johann Baptist Zimmermann. La pi√π famosa √® la Steinerne Saal, che si estende su tre piani, la galleria delle bellezze del re Ludovico I, tra gli altri. con il ritratto della sua Lola Montez e la stanza natale del re Ludovico II, tutto in seta verde.Nonostante gli interni della residenza siano davvero notevoli devo dire che ci√≤ che mi ha colpito di pi√π in assoluto durante la mia visita √® stata la ricercata bellezza ed eleganza dei padiglioni costruiti nel parco del castello. L'Amalienburg √® uno splendido padiglione di caccia in stile rococ√≤ progettato sempre dal Cuvilli√©s e realizzato per l'imperatrice Maria Amalia (la moglie di Carlo VII), grande appassionata di caccia.  Eccezionale la sala degli specchi Ma anche la cucina mi ha colpito moltissimo Anzi alla fine ho passato molto pi√π tempo in cucina a guardare da vicino le mattonelle di ceramica (dipinte a mano con paesaggi e scene di vita quotidiana o motivi floreali, tutte diverse una dall'altra) che nella sala degli specchi. Gli spettacolari sono le figure della Commedia dell'arte di Franz Anton Bustelli e le belle opere di Dominik Auliczek del 1770 anche le opere di artisti regionali trovano posto nel Museo.Le sale del castello e i padiglioni del parco nella bella stagione (dal 1 aprile al 15 ottobre) sono aperti dalle 9:00 alle 18:00, mentre dal 16 ottobre al 31 marzo il palazzo osserva l'orario invernale e le sale sono visitabili solo dalle 10:00 alle 16:00 (mentre i padiglioni sono chiusi).Nota: alcuni degli edifici possono essere visitati solo durante la stagione estiva.

title: Beautiful Royal Palace
text: This is one of the largest and grandest palaces in Bavaria and is a must see if you are anywhere near Munich.  This palace has been the summer home to Holy Roman Emperors and was the birthplace for King Ludwig II (of Neuschwanstein Castle fame).  Throughout the palace is a collection of richly decorated walls and ceilings, expensive furnishings, tapestries and paintings.  Highlights include the "Gallery of Beauties" commissioned by King Ludwig, King Ludwig's stateroom/bedroom and the impressive banquet hall.  The Palace is surrounded by manicured gardens, fountains and waterways.  This palace is also famous for its famous carriage and porcelain museums.  Information on each exhibit is presented in both German and English.  The Palace is open April through mid-October from 9 AM to 6 PM and from mid-October to March from 9 AM to 4 PM.  Price of admission is 6 euros (5 euros reduced fare) for the Nymphenburg Palace and 4.5 euros each (3.5 euros reduced fare for the carriage and porcelain museums.  A combination ticket for all of this plus the smaller park palaces is 8.5 euros (6.5 euros reduced).  We took  tram #17 from the Munich Altstadt/Old town (Karlsplatz Station) to within a few blocks of the palace and it was a very easy to get to. title: The inside was better than I expected!
text: From the photos I thought it'd be a bit too gaudy for my tastes, but we couldn't believe the style and detail from the ceilings down. One of the workers said we shouldn't try to see everything in one day, and could use out ticket for several days, but we had to leave Germany the next morning. The geese instantly recognized the bag, and started to surround him. I don't know if most people know how aggressive geese can be, but I got worried and stood between him and the birds with my arms open wide, to block and scare them away. They didn't look very scared, just a little annoyed, and decided to leave him alone. Don't leave small children unattended with bread! The birds might be more persistent if they think they can get away with bread-theft.

text: The castle of Nymphenburg lies in the west of Munich. The construction was started 1664 and in 1679 the castle was almost completed in its first form. During the reign of Elector Max Emanuel (1680-1726)Nymphenburg Palace was given its present dimension. One of the attractions in the interior of the castle are the beauty gallery of King Ludwig I and the birth room of King Ludwig II of Bavaria ( builder of the famous castles ) who was born there on August 25, 1845. This location is a must do if you stay in Munich.
